image.altText: Three-year-old William Tyrrell has been missing from his NSW mid north coast home since late last week.

items.synopsis: NSW detectives recommend William Tyrrell's foster mother be charged with covering up the death of the three year old who went missing in 2014.

title.children: Detectives recommend charges against William Tyrrell's foster mother over toddler's disappearance

image.altText: Police officers and cars outside building with police tape

items.synopsis: Detectives have found a firearm left behind at one of the crime scenes after Tuesday's shooting death of a prominent Sydney underworld figure, which may be the potential murder weapon.

title.children: Pistol found by police at Bondi Junction crime scene where drug kingpin was found dead

image.altText: flight runways at a new airport getting built

items.synopsis: People across Western Sydney have gained a clearer idea of how the new international airport, opening in 2026, will affect them — and some are describing it as a "nightmare scenario".

title.children: Residents divided after Western Sydney airport proposed flight paths released

image.altText: Scott Morrison on a construction site.

items.synopsis: Multiple previously secret reports scrutinising the $2.3 billion HomeBuilder scheme have found a lack of governance, controls and risk management.

title.children: HomeBuilder scheme 'overheated' construction and blindsided states, reports find

image.altText: A man in a suit with his arms folded

items.synopsis: New details of the case emerge in court, with the Sydney businessman accused of selling Australian defence and security secrets in China.

title.children: Sydney man accused of foreign interference was warned to leave China by suspected US spy, court hears

image.altText: Loy Yang Power Station

items.synopsis: Australia's energy transition has reached a tipping point, and experts are warning consumers to brace for a bumpy ride over the next decade.

title.children: Higher power prices the 'new normal' as Australia moves towards cleaner future

image.altText: Gambling advertisement at an AFL game.

items.synopsis: Committee chair Peta Murphy says Australians are among the biggest gambling losers anywhere in the world, and previous attempts to regulate gambling advertising have failed to address the problem.

title.children: Gambling ads should be banned within three years to tackle addiction crisis, parliamentary committee says

image.altText: An alleged Australian-built cardboard drone lies nose down with a twig stuck in it

items.synopsis: Photos appear online purporting to show an Australian-made drone that recently crashed inside Russian territory with an explosive strapped to it.

title.children: Pro-Putin military bloggers claim Australian-built cardboard drone was brought down inside Russia

image.altText: Servicemen sit in a tank with a flag of the Wagner Group military company.

items.synopsis: When Ivan Rossomakhin returned home from the war in Ukraine three months ago, his neighbours in the village east of Moscow were terrified.

title.children: A convicted murderer fought for Wagner in Ukraine. Ten days after returning to Russia, he allegedly killed an elderly woman

image.altText: An illustration of a library, featuring a desk with a blue box containing a head.

items.synopsis: With mystery surrounding its origins, the mummified head poses all sorts of questions about the past, present and future.

title.children: 'A rite of passage': The regional high school with a mummified human head

image.altText: Jason Clare speaks at a lecturn in front of Australian flags

items.synopsis: The education minister describes PwC's failure to disclose its interest in Top Education Group, while conducting a confidential review into the regulator of private colleges, as "completely unacceptable".

title.children: PwC's failure to disclose interest in private education provider 'completely unacceptable'

image.altText: Ben Stokes holds his face as Pat Cummins looks at his bat

items.synopsis: As England heads into the second Ashes Test desperately needing to win, the players are bullish about their chances. Here's everything you need to know ahead of tonight's first ball.

title.children: England 'felt like' they won the first Ashes Test, but they didn't — so will they change their approach tonight?

image.altText: The back of a man's head looking at a ASX sign

items.synopsis: US stocks rallied as strong economic data eased recession fears. Inflation tipped to cool ahead of RBA meeting. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Wall Street gains on strong economic data, all eyes on latest inflation figures

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Treasurer Jim Chalmers is forecasting the budget surplus for 2022/23 will be "significantly" bigger than the $4.2 billion estimated in May's budget. Revenue has been driven by the strong employment market, higher commodity prices and company profits. Mr Chalmers has been speaking to the Property Council of Australia in the Northern Territory this morning. "One of the big priorities we came into government with was getting the Budget on a more sustainable footing," he says. "And the improvements in revenue that we’ve seen in recent times – driven by a combination of good prices for our exports and a consistently strong labour market – have helped us in that task. " Mr Chalmers says restraining annual real spending growth and finding $40 billion worth of savings have helped the bottom line. "We said in May that we expected all this to result in a surplus for 2022-23 – the first in 15 years." "We were deliberately cautious and conservative, restrained and responsible when it came to this, given this history." "So, I’m pleased to say that two days out from the end of the financial year, we’re still on track." "In fact, we’re in a significantly better position than we forecast." "Today, I can reveal that we’re expecting the surplus will be bigger than forecast in May."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Budget surplus expected to be larger than forecast

children.content: Treasurer Jim Chalmers is forecasting the budget surplus for 2022/23 will be "significantly" bigger than the $4.2 billion estimated in May's budget.
Revenue has been driven by the strong employment market, higher commodity prices and company profits.
Mr Chalmers has been speaking to the Property Council of Australia in the Northern Territory this morning.
"One of the big priorities we came into government with was getting the Budget on a more sustainable footing," he says.
"And the improvements in revenue that we’ve seen in recent times – driven by a combination of good prices for our exports and a consistently strong labour market – have helped us in that task. "
Mr Chalmers says restraining annual real spending growth and finding $40 billion worth of savings have helped the bottom line.
"We said in May that we expected all this to result in a surplus for 2022-23 – the first in 15 years."
"We were deliberately cautious and conservative, restrained and responsible when it came to this, given this history."
"So, I’m pleased to say that two days out from the end of the financial year, we’re still on track."
"In fact, we’re in a significantly better position than we forecast."
"Today, I can reveal that we’re expecting the surplus will be bigger than forecast in May."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Swiss investment bank UBS is set to cut more than half of Credit Suisse's workforce according to Bloomberg. UBS completed its emergency takeover of Credit Suisse earlier this month as part of a state led bailout. The move created a banking giant with a $US1.6 trillion balance sheet and a workforce of 120,000. Bloomberg reports that UBS wants to cut total staff by one third of 35,000 people. Credit Suisse has around 45,000 staff.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: UBS to slash Credit Suisse workforce by half

children.content: Swiss investment bank UBS is set to cut more than half of Credit Suisse's workforce according to Bloomberg.
UBS completed its emergency takeover of Credit Suisse earlier this month as part of a state led bailout.
The move created a banking giant with a $US1.6 trillion balance sheet and a workforce of 120,000.
Bloomberg reports that UBS wants to cut total staff by one third of 35,000 people.
Credit Suisse has around 45,000 staff.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, and welcome to the ABC's Markets Blog. Overnight US stocks rallied as robust economic data soothed worries about a recession. The Dow Jones index put on 0.6 per cent. New orders for US manufactured capital goods rose in May, sales of new single family homes surged, and US consumer confidence increased to the highest in nearly one and half years. And oil prices slumped more than 2 per cent on signs of more rate rises from central banks. The Australian dollar is trading around 66.87 US cents. Later this morning, the Bureau of Statistics will release consumer inflation figures for May. Inflation is expected to have risen by 6.1 per cent over the year, a pull back from the 6.8 per cent rise over the year to April. We will have the figures live when they are released at 11:30am AEST.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US stocks rise

children.content: Good morning, and welcome to the ABC's Markets Blog.
Overnight US stocks rallied as robust economic data soothed worries about a recession.
The Dow Jones index put on 0.6 per cent.
New orders for US manufactured capital goods rose in May, sales of new single family homes surged, and US consumer confidence increased to the highest in nearly one and half years.
And oil prices slumped more than 2 per cent on signs of more rate rises from central banks.
The Australian dollar is trading around 66.87 US cents.
Later this morning, the Bureau of Statistics will release consumer inflation figures for May.
Inflation is expected to have risen by 6.1 per cent over the year, a pull back from the 6.8 per cent rise over the year to April.
We will have the figures live when they are released at 11:30am AEST.

image.altText: An ambulance at the scene of a night-time incident at a retirement.

items.synopsis: The cause of the fire at the North Coast retirement facility is under investigation.

title.children: Woman dies at scene of retirement home blaze in NSW

image.altText: Convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein in his 2017 mug shot.

items.synopsis: The US Justice Department's internal watchdog singles out 13 prison employees for "misconduct and dereliction of their duties".

title.children: Scathing report finds prison guard misconduct led to Jeffrey Epstein's suicide

image.altText: a tub of coyo yogburt sitting on a bench in the sun

items.synopsis: A Sunshine Coast company which manufactures "dairy-free" coconut yoghurt and ice cream products is being sued in the Queensland Supreme Court following a woman's death in the UK.

title.children: Queensland 'dairy-free' yoghurt manufacturer COYO sued after UK woman's anaphylaxis death

image.altText: Flames and smoke rose from a house burning in the town of Goroka.

items.synopsis: Tribal violence has displaced thousands in Papua New Guinea's highlands, and losing identity documents in the destruction has made moving on with their lives a "cumbersome" process.

title.children: Hundreds of PNG tribal violence victims struggling to prove their identity after IDs destroyed

image.altText: A diver swims up to an orange coral in the sea.

items.synopsis: Researchers say the discovery in an underwater passage off the Pilbara coast provides "critical evidence" of major changes in the landscape.

title.children: Stone artefacts discovered 14m underwater at Australia's deepest known ancient Aboriginal site

image.altText: An angry look cassowary looks up at the camera.

items.synopsis: The endangered southern cassowary looks akin to its prehistoric ancestors and there's a national push to save this "beautiful" giant bird from disappearing.

title.children: Renewed push to save southern cassowary, Australia's own 'living dinosaur'

image.altText: an aerial view of a station homestead and a cattle feedlot.

items.synopsis: Helicopter charter company Top End Mustering said the highly experienced pilot was performing routine mustering when their Robinson R22 chopper crashed on Tuesday.

title.children: Pilot killed after helicopter crashes during mustering operations on remote station

image.altText: A man embraces a woman who is crying in fading light.

items.synopsis: Emergency services scurried in and out of the shattered restaurant as residents stood outside surveying the damage from the strike, which occurred just before 8pm local time on Tuesday night.

title.children: Deadly Russian missile strikes hit popular restaurant in Ukraine's Donetsk region, killing four

image.altText: Yevgeny Prighozin angrily pointing a finger

items.synopsis: Russian authorities have closed a criminal investigation into the aborted armed rebellion led by mercenary chief Yevgeny Prigozhin, and are pressing no charges against him or his troops.

title.children: Wagner chief enters Belarus as Lukashenko ponders his military value

image.altText: Julian Sands wearing open-neck blue shirt and purple jacket staring into camera.

items.synopsis: British-born actor Julian Sands, best known for his role in the Oscar-celebrated film A Room with a View, is confirmed dead, five months after he went missing while out for a hike in snow-covered mountains near Los Angeles.

title.children: Actor Julian Sands confirmed dead five months after he disappeared on hike

image.altText: A stained glass church window with a decorative pattern in green, orange and red glass

items.synopsis: Catholic Education Tasmania is reviewing a religious instruction course planned for college students next year after feedback from principals. An LGBTIQA+ support group has called it "discriminatory" and has threatened to lodge formal complaints.

title.children: 'Discriminatory' school course focusing on conservative Catholic values under review

image.altText: The back of a white ute, with the word "Jovi" graffitied on the back in black spraypaint.

items.synopsis: The Jon Bon Jovi Boys, or Jovi Boys, hail from a remote community of less than 200 people. Residents there say they're "terrorising" the community and they've had enough of their bad behaviour.

title.children: 'They've got no respect': Jon Bon Jovi Boys outback gang in sights of NT police

image.altText: A white bus on its side surrounded by emergency services personnel in high vis.

items.synopsis: Private ambulance crews asked to help on the day of last month’s horror Eynesbury school bus crash were instead directed to do non-urgent private contract jobs, workers have alleged, saying operators are putting profit over patient care every day.

title.children: Private ambulance operators allegedly directed staff to contract jobs on day of Eynesbury school bus crash

image.altText: An octogenarian white man in a brown hat and jacket stands in a town square with a white brunette woman in a white hat and shirt

items.synopsis: Taking over the reins from George Lucas and Steven Spielberg, director James Mangold had his work cut out for him bringing this four-decade story to a close. Did he succeed?

title.children: Harrison Ford and Phoebe Waller-Bridge hunt treasure and punch Nazis in Indiana Jones finale

image.altText: Older man wearing navy fleece top, grey vest and cap stands in front of truck smiling at camera.

items.synopsis: A rusty but precious piece of history returns to the Snowy Mountains to be restored and displayed in a museum.

title.children: Original Snowy Scheme truck returns home after decades spent rusting in paddock

image.altText: A man in a tuxedo speaks at a dais.

items.synopsis: Port Adelaide's only AFL premiership coach uses his Hall of Fame speech to back the Voice referendum, as seven new faces are added to the illustrious group.

title.children: 'We have to do the right thing': Hall of Fame inductee uses speech to laud AFL's Voice stance

image.altText: A young woman with blonde hair sits in a room and smiles

items.synopsis: The sister of missing Belgian tourist Celine Cremer makes a plea on social media for help locating the 31-year-old, with police concerned for her welfare after locating her car in a waterfall car park.

title.children: 'Help us find her': Sister's plea as police locate car of missing Belgian tourist

image.altText: aerial of ship spraying sea water

items.synopsis: Queensland scientists are the first to practically test the cloud brightening theory, shooting sea spray over the Great Barrier Reef.

title.children: Could brightening clouds help tackle climate change? These scientists are trying to find out

image.altText: Donald Trump pictured making a fist while speaking into microphone at podium with US flag in background.

items.synopsis: The audio file includes a moment when Mr Trump seems to indicate he is holding a secret Pentagon document with plans to attack Iran, and he refers to something as "highly confidential" and "secret information".

title.children: Donald Trump says recording of him discussing secret documents is 'actually an exoneration'

image.altText: A composite of two images of a man with a beard and a blue shirt carving an old brick wall.

items.synopsis: Italy's culture and tourism ministers vow to find and punish a tourist who was filmed carving into the wall of Rome's Colosseum.

title.children: Tourist filmed carving his and girlfriend's name into Colosseum faces $24,550 fine

image.altText: A grey monkey swinging between trees.

items.synopsis: Four decades ago there were just 50 northern mariquis left in Brazil's Atlantic forest and the Americas' biggest monkey was threatened with extinction.

title.children: The Americas' biggest monkey returns from the brink of extinction
